Award.AwardTitle: Microanalytical Techniques to Study Single Cell Biochemical Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professor Susan Lunte, in collaboration with Professors Christian Sch√∂neich (University of Kansas), Christopher Culbertson (Kansas State University) and Christian Amatore (Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, CNRS), will develop new analytical methodologies that can be used to investigate chemical reactions in single biological cells. A central focus of the research will be the development of microfluidic devices for manipulating single cells and conducting measurements of cell chemical reactions using electrical and optical techniques. Microfluidic devices are ultrasmall plumbing networks of channels and valves which can precisely manage small volumes of liquids (one-millionth to a few billionths of a liter). Microfluidics thus enable the study of small systems such as living cells, and also the rapid collection of data. This project is a multidisciplinary/international collaboration between four research groups, each providing unique expertise and facilities. Graduate students will be part of an interdisciplinary team and will acquire training in the fields of chemistry, microfluidics, cell biology, and neurobiology. As part of this project, microfluidics will be integrated into the problem-based learning portion of the instrumental analysis course at the University of Kansas.

The proposed methods are based on microchip electrophoresis with electrochemical detection. Microchip electrophoresis permits the separation of multiple species, and electrochemical detection is particularly well-suited for interrogating the redox status of cells. The focus of the proposed studies is on methods for the detection and identification of reactive nitrogen and oxygen species and endogenous antioxidants such as glutathione. A high throughput single cell analysis system with combined electrochemical and fluorescence detection that is capable of monitoring cell redox status as a function of cell phenotype and activation state will also be developed. These new tools will be used to investigate the processes involved in inflammation and neurodegeneration at both the chemical and biological levels.

Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The brain and heart are particularly susceptible to the damaging effects of oxidative stress due to their high metabolic rates and relatively low capacities for tissue regeneration. Macrophages and microglia are the immune cells of the periphery and the brain, respectively. Under inflammatory conditions, these cells can generate oxidative stress through the production of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (RNOS). In this grant, methods for the separation and detection of these reactive species in individual cells were developed. Our approach used microfluidics to manipulate cells and perform the analysis. Microfluidics has the advantage of fast reproducible analyses, making it possible to perform high throughput analysis and detect short-lived chemical species. During the grant period, a high throughput single cell analysis system capable of measuring the contents of 1000 individual cells in 1 hour was developed. This was combined with a unique multimode fluorescence detector capable of tracking a cell from the point of introduction into the microfluidic chip, cell lysis, and detection of the RNOS molecules. Methods for the simultaneous detection of several different RNOS in the same cell sample using fluorescence detection were also developed.

Electrochemistry is a particularly useful method for the direct detection of molecules involved in oxidative stress since these molecules, by definition, are easily oxidized.  Several electrochemical detection methods were investigated for the direct and indirect detection of reactive nitrogen species that are generated during inflammation. These included a novel detection approach that converts the electrochemical response to fluorescence to improve limits of detection. Progress was also made concerning the integration of both fluorescence and electrochemical detection with the single cell analysis system.  The methodology developed in this grant will provide tools that can be used to better understand the biochemical processes involved in immune cell activation as they relate to cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases. It could also be used for the investigation of other inflammatory processes and diseases, including cancer and diabetes. Another application is the use of this methodology to study the effects of drugs and natural products on oxidative stress in vivo. During this grant period, we investigated the effect of a natural antioxidant, carnosine, on oxidative stress caused by inflammatory agents and found that it reduced the amount of RNOS produced by immune cells.

This project was a multidisciplinary collaboration between four research groups, each providing unique expertise and facilities. The team consisted of undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and international scholars who met on a regular basis. Students trained as part of this project acquired training in the fields of microfluidics, cell biology, neurobiology, and chemistry. Several of the undergraduate students were from underrepresented groups in STEM.  Microfluidics was also introduced into the Advanced Analytical Lab as part of a problem-based learning project. Lastly, a considerable amount of effort was spent on communication skills, and students and postdocs were encouraged to present their work at local, national, and international conferences.

 


 


Last Modified: 12/21/2017
Modified by: Susan M Lunte

Under inflammatory conditions, these cells can generate oxidative stress through the production of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (RNOS). Microfluidics has the advantage of fast reproducible analyses, making it possible to perform high throughput analysis and detect short-lived chemical species. Methods for the simultaneous detection of several different RNOS in the same cell sample using fluorescence detection were also developed. Electrochemistry is a particularly useful method for the direct detection of molecules involved in oxidative stress since these molecules, by definition, are easily oxidized. Several electrochemical detection methods were investigated for the direct and indirect detection of reactive nitrogen species that are generated during inflammation. These included a novel detection approach that converts the electrochemical response to fluorescence to improve limits of detection. Progress was also made concerning the integration of both fluorescence and electrochemical detection with the single cell analysis system. The methodology developed in this grant will provide tools that can be used to better understand the biochemical processes involved in immune cell activation as they relate to cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases. It could also be used for the investigation of other inflammatory processes and diseases, including cancer and diabetes. Another application is the use of this methodology to study the effects of drugs and natural products on oxidative stress in vivo. During this grant period, we investigated the effect of a natural antioxidant, carnosine, on oxidative stress caused by inflammatory agents and found that it reduced the amount of RNOS produced by immune cells. The team consisted of undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and international scholars who met on a regular basis.
